title: 113_s1415
content:
The Act is titled the "Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance Act of 2013" and includes definitions for clarity. The Act titled the "Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance Act of 2013" defines "Federal land" as approximately 17,826 acres depicted on a specific map and "planning area" as land administered by the Bureau of Land Management in various districts. The term "public domain land" is defined as "public lands" in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, excluding land managed under a specific Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and "Tribe" refers to the Cow Creek Band of Umpqua Tribe of Indians. SEC. 3. CONVEYANCE.

Subject to existing rights, all US right, title, and interest in Federal land, including improvements, appurtenances, and minerals, shall be held in trust for the Tribe and part of their reservation. A survey to establish boundaries must be completed within 180 days.

SEC. 4. MAP AND LEGAL DESCRIPTION. SEC. 4. MAP AND LEGAL DESCRIPTION. The Secretary will file a map and legal description of Federal land with specified committees. The filed map and legal description will have the same force as if included in the Act and will be available for public inspection. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION. This section clarifies that existing tribal rights to land are unaffected by the Act. It also prohibits the export of unprocessed logs from Federal land and restricts the use of land acquired under the Act for gaming activities. The Act requires the Secretary of Agriculture to identify Oregon and California Railroad land for conveyance within 180 days. Public domain land of similar acreage and condition must be identified within 18 months. Maps depicting the identified lands must be submitted to Congress within 2 years. After public comment, the Secretary will reclassify the land as owned by the Oregon and California Railroad. The Act of August 28, 1937 will apply to the reclassified land.
